subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Wow. This is really cool! Helps understand some things more intuitively.

I like this! We have both `exp` and `log` for when the parameters are
enormous, and the clearer superscripts when they're manageable.

I like this! We have both `exp` and `log` for when the parameters are enormous, and the clearer superscripts when they're manageable.

#THIS #IS #AWESOME

Like one of the coolest things I’ve seen in a long time. Eliana, really great work!

Seeing this makes me curious: Is there an equivalent of base change for regular exponentiation?

————————————————————————————————————
Rafael Cosman, Stanford CS 2015

Rafael's Phone: 858-775-2858
Rafael’s Schedule

Here are two awesome projects that I’m working on, both related to CS-education: Cosmos and Code Camp

From: Eliana Lorch elianalorch@gmail.com
Reply: Eliana Lorch elianalorch@gmail.com
Date: May 9, 2014 at 3:24:44 PM
To: Rafael Cosman rafaelc@stanford.edu
Cc: Gary Antonick antonick@stanford.edu, hackhex hackhex@googlegroups.com
Subject:  Re: Logarithms

I tried re-imagining logarithms as being a left hand exponent and made a table of some common things. It feels a bit more clear to me (especially in that it's closely tied to exponentials), but perhaps not. The power rule is the most confusing in the new notation (but not more so than it usually looks perhaps?). What do you think?




On 9 May 2014 14:31, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
What if we had a notation for logarithms that was as nice as our notation for exponentiation? Maybe math with logarithms would become much easier.

Could stable coins solve this?

On Wed, Mar 6, 2019 at 10:21 AM Eric Liu <ericsliu@gmail.com> wrote:
Rafael - I've heard of a group (forgot the name) that's experimenting with airdropping stablecoins to mobile phones in places without strong fiat. I think refugees are part of the target group as well, since they might not have any form of identification or access to bank accounts from their home country.

On Sun, 3 Mar 2019 at 16:00, Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Jacob— I think that's interesting. I'd love to learn more about the regulations in the US around that. I'm surprised that it's allowed given that it's creating currencies that compete with the US dollar for commerce (as opposed to TrueUSD which is just another form of USD, similar to Venmo).

Jiannan— Security tokens are an application that we're looking into and we're starting to form partnerships there. But the actual volume of security tokens right now is still very small.

Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!

A big set of applications that I’m looking into now is to use stable coins to buy and trade security tokens.

Jiannan

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf

Co-Founder

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf

subject: Re: What application for Stablecoins do you see?

Might be worth looking at tokenizing currencies in developing countries or countries with less liquid currency markets due to currency controls. Many of the financial derivative products available with USD are not available to those trading currencies such as the Malaysian Ringgit. 

Seems like tokenizing fiat right now is a form of legal arbitrage or more accessible money market fund, I am curious to learn what other applications there will be.

Jacob—

MakerDAO just prototyped this at ETHDenver with a version of its Dai stablecoin called Buffidai, that was set up so attendees could spend it on the food vendors, but only the vendors could convert it back to normal Dai.

Also, you should check out the story of Sardex if you haven’t already.
On Sun, Mar 3, 2019 at 4:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Jacob— I think that's interesting. I'd love to learn more about the regulations in the US around that. I'm surprised that it's allowed given that it's creating currencies that compete with the US dollar for commerce (as opposed to TrueUSD which is just another form of USD, similar to Venmo).

A big set of applications that I’m looking into now is to use stable coins to buy and trade security tokens.

Jiannan

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder
TrustToken - We're hiring!

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

On Mar 2, 2019, at 2:20 AM, Jacob Cole <tmad4000@gmail.com> wrote:

 I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

 
On Fri, Mar 1, 2019 at 8:00 PM Rafael Cosman <rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu> wrote:
Hey Hacksphere, our team has launched one of the largest USD stablecoins, TrueUSD, and grown it to about $200mm in the last year. (A stablecoin is a price-stable cryptocurrency. Every TrueUSD is backed by a US Dollar sitting in a big bank account.)

We're looking to launch several other tokenized currencies this year and are thinking about the possible applications that these products could unlock, including forex, remittances, and much more.

I'd love to get thoughts on what applications you see for tokenized fiat currencies such as TrueUSD, TrueGBP, etc.

Best,
Raf


rafaelcosman@alumni.stanford.edu
Co-Founder

is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“
currency for?

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of
“fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be
exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions?

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and
regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement
(maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins
could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly,
as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a
FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling
 exploitative  practices.

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all
carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,
 or other externalities.

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to
China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group?
(Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I
don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up
with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

I fairly recently learned that some towns, in order to support local businesses, have issued local currencies that all of the local businesses agree to accept as money.  Not only does this prevent big chains from sucking these towns’ economies dry and killing all of the mom and pop stores (RIP Old Palo Alto), but it enables  the local government to create local economic stimulus packages without relying on the federal government. 

 As society  becomes increasingly interconnected, it’s not necessarily the physical  geography that determines what a “local” area or local community is.    What other groupings could  it makes sense to issue a “local“ currency for? 

 For instance  what if there were a currency created for the economy of “fair trade“ businesses —  businesses that are certified not to be exploiting workers or have terrible labor conditions? 

 For one, this is an economy it would be great to be able to stimulate and regulate without waiting for lots of governments to make an agreement (maybe the decision about whether to release more coins or sequester coins could be run at the smart contract based vote of all members?).  Secondly, as a consumer, you would know that if you bought something with a FairTradeCoin,  you wouldn’t have to worry that you were enabling  exploitative  practices. 

Maybe another currency could be created just for the conmunity of all carbon neutral businesses — businesses that offset their carbon emissions,  or other externalities. 

 Or maybe for US businesses that don’t outsource their manufacturing to China?

 Or maybe a currency for businesses managed by members of a minority group? (Eg women?)

 Please feel free to tell me that none of this is a valid idea at all. I don’t necessarily think this is at all the best idea this group can come up with for uses of Raf’s coin.  Interested to hear your thoughts.

subject: Re: Thanks
content:
Regarding the Gestalt-loop closing news source - it's worth examining
current news disseminators who come close to your idea but are not
completely there yet.

1. The Guardian (UK news publisher) sometimes releases "story trackers" -
essentially, a single page which aggregates separate news stories relating
to a topic. The fact that all of the news stories come from the same
publisher makes integration simple and clean, and it appears that they make
an attempt at comment integration. Unfortunately, this article mentions
that the Guardian only tracks science stories.
http://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2010/jun/09/science-story-trackers

2. When the Boston Marathon bombings were underway, there were many story
trackers out there, some run by news publishers, and some run by
independent bloggers. The ability to aggregate all of the stories with
opinions and minor updates of an event as it unfolds is crucial. Here is
one example blogger who tracked the bombings.
http://ksj.mit.edu/tracker/2013/04/boston-marathon-developing-story

3. We have Wikinews, which enables collaborative editing of individual news
stories. They don't have collaboratively edited story trackers. This is a
great area of opportunity - we can repurpose collaboratively edited story
trackers to follow entire issues, such as the attempt to make healthcare
more accessible to Americans, from start to finish. A terrific way of
closing open Gestalts.

I feel some ideas coming together. If anyone would like to work with me to
design and prototype a web app which fills this function, let me know.

-JamesFW

Olin College '15
https://github.com/jimmyfw



On Sat, Nov 30, 2013 at 11:53 PM, Max Novendstern <mnovendstern@gmail.com>wrote:

> Great talk Jacob!
>
> As an audience member, I would love more specific examples of what
> "closing a gestalt" looks like. And then -- just as important -- what
> happens once it's closed.
>
> Some scattered thoughts:
>
> - Is the notion of an "efficient market" directly applicable to, if not
> entirely comprehensive of, your goal? "A more efficient market for matching
> up people who [want to work on a given project]..."
>
> - I want to pressure you to take seriously the limits of "awareness" as a
> solvent for social problems.
>
> Take corruption in Congress. Many people are aware that Congressional
> Reps. spend 30%-70% of their time raising money from .05% the U.S.
> population. It's part of the reason Congress has less support today than
> the British Parliament did on the eve of the Revolution!
>
> But greater "transparency" -- or better "markets" connecting passionate
> people with organizations -- is not obviously what's needed. Consider this:
> in the case of campaign finance reform, the facts can be distorting.
>
> The casual reader -- your proverbial "bomb in Baghdad" news consumer --
> might conclude that a congresswoman is corrupt because she took money from
> some group, or that she's not corrupt because she didn't take money from
> that group, when in truth, the nature of corruption in Congress is subtle
> and deep, far more complex than the casual reader would rationally want to
> spend their finite time comprehending.
>
> In fact, this is a general principle: our active memories are finite. So
> the fewer things we're forced to fit into them, the more rational we can be
> about the things we want to think about. It's often said that a great trap
> of poverty is that so many fewer facts are "settled." It's doubly hard to
> take care of your family, or make to optimal career decisions, when you
> have to fill your active memory with issues about where you'll find food,
> whether the electricity is working, and how you're going to transport
> yourself from one place to another.
>
> At best, food, electricity, and transportation "just work." The less you *have
> *to know, the better. And this is true of a host of social issues.
>
> Here's my point. Corruption in Congress will be solved by institutional
> change. We'll change the laws. In the process, if more people know more
> things, that's great! It may be useful to the cause. But don't think it's
> intrinsically valuable. To the contrary, knowledge about everything cannot
> and should not be achieved. To say it more provocatively: keeping people
> ignorant (about things that will waste their finite active memories) is a
> great social good! In this specific sense, I'm pro ignorance.
>
> Max
>
>
>
>
> On Sat, Nov 30, 2013 at 11:16 PM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
>
>> Hey, didn't Stuart Armstrong speak at a Transhumanist Association thingy
>> once?
>>
>> Best Regards,
>> Howon Lee
>>
>>

2. When the Boston Marathon bombings were underway, there were many story trackers out there, some run by news publishers, and some run by independent bloggers. The ability to aggregate all of the stories with opinions and minor updates of an event as it unfolds is crucial. Here is one example blogger who tracked the bombings.
http://ksj.mit.edu/tracker/2013/04/boston-marathon-developing-story

3. We have Wikinews, which enables collaborative editing of individual news stories. They don't have collaboratively edited story trackers. This is a great area of opportunity - we can repurpose collaboratively edited story trackers to follow entire issues, such as the attempt to make healthcare more accessible to Americans, from start to finish. A terrific way of closing open Gestalts.

I feel some ideas coming together. If anyone would like to work with me to design and prototype a web app which fills this function, let me know.

-JamesFW

Olin College '15
https://github.com/jimmyfw



On Sat, Nov 30, 2013 at 11:53 PM, Max Novendstern <mnovendstern@gmail.com> wrote:
Great talk Jacob!

As an audience member, I would love more specific examples of what "closing a gestalt" looks like. And then -- just as important -- what happens once it's closed.

Some scattered thoughts:

- Is the notion of an "efficient market" directly applicable to, if not entirely comprehensive of, your goal? "A more efficient market for matching up people who [want to work on a given project]..."

- I want to pressure you to take seriously the limits of "awareness" as a solvent for social problems.

Take corruption in Congress. Many people are aware that Congressional Reps. spend 30%-70% of their time raising money from .05% the U.S. population. It's part of the reason Congress has less support today than the British Parliament did on the eve of the Revolution!

But greater "transparency" -- or better "markets" connecting passionate people with organizations -- is not obviously what's needed. Consider this: in the case of campaign finance reform, the facts can be distorting.

The casual reader -- your proverbial "bomb in Baghdad" news consumer -- might conclude that a congresswoman is corrupt because she took money from some group, or that she's not corrupt because she didn't take money from that group, when in truth, the nature of corruption in Congress is subtle and deep, far more complex than the casual reader would rationally want to spend their finite time comprehending.

In fact, this is a general principle: our active memories are finite. So the fewer things we're forced to fit into them, the more rational we can be about the things we want to think about. It's often said that a great trap of poverty is that so many fewer facts are "settled." It's doubly hard to take care of your family, or make to optimal career decisions, when you have to fill your active memory with issues about where you'll find food, whether the electricity is working, and how you're going to transport yourself from one place to another.

At best, food, electricity, and transportation "just work." The less you have to know, the better. And this is true of a host of social issues.

Here's my point. Corruption in Congress will be solved by institutional change. We'll change the laws. In the process, if more people know more things, that's great! It may be useful to the cause. But don't think it's intrinsically valuable. To the contrary, knowledge about everything cannot and should not be achieved. To say it more provocatively: keeping people ignorant (about things that will waste their finite active memories) is a great social good! In this specific sense, I'm pro ignorance.

Max

subject: Fwd: We've got 72 hours to save SB 50
content:
The future of CA is in the balance. Do you want a California with housing
our generation could actually afford? Please join me in calling for a vote
for SB50 this year, the most important state legislation in the cards. It’s
been shot down undemocratically and it needs to move forward now.

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Laura from YIMBY Action <hello@yimbyaction.org>
Date: Fri, May 17, 2019 at 10:44
Subject: We've got 72 hours to save SB 50
To: <me@omardiab.com>


This is your rallying call for More HOMES and other important housing bills.
Don't let this stand. Demand a Vote for SB 50!

Yesterday Senate Bill 50, the MoreHOMES Act, had a major setback
<https://yimbyaction.us15.list-manage.com/track/click?u=80dc2a6db6f9f02cf3a35eaf9&id=09cc660165&e=e1a5869b2d>.
This
bill has the potential to vastly increase home building near mass transit
and in single-family home neighborhoods across California - *and it ain't
over.*

Senate President pro tempore Toni Atkins has the power to save Senate Bill
50 and ensure a floor vote before the end of May. She'll only do that if
people demand it.

That's where you come in.
1) Ask Senator Atkins to bring SB 50 for a vote.

Tell her office that you want SB 50 to be voted on the floor of the State
Senate *this legislative session*.

Across the state, ask your friends to make this call. If you have a network
in* San Diego*, we especially hope they can call Senator Atkins.

*Senator Toni Atkins*
(916) 651-4039

*Optional Script: *
Hi, my name is _____. I’m calling because SB 50, the More HOMES Act, is
extremely important to me. I live in _____ and I'm tired of seeing how high
housing costs are damaging my community. It's time to bring the More HOMES
Act to the Senate floor. *We need a vote THIS YEAR.*
2) Express Yourself, using #MoreHOMESthisyear

Whether it's short tweet tagging @SenToniAtkins or a long medium post, ask
for a vote *this year* for SB 50. You can write a Facebook screed, a
Tweetstorm, a Nextdoor rant or share a long email to your elected
officials. Use the long list of endorsers from the SB 50 Fact Sheet
<https://yimbyaction.us15.list-manage.com/track/click?u=80dc2a6db6f9f02cf3a35eaf9&id=08750eb592&e=e1a5869b2d>
to
back up your case.

Find other people's pro-SB 50 comments and elevate them. *The drumbeat on
social media must be undeniable.* Tag @yimbyaction or email us your content
and we'll share them.
3) Keep the momentum going

*Forward this email to a friend.*
<http://us15.forward-to-friend.com/forward?u=80dc2a6db6f9f02cf3a35eaf9&id=7f87ccce27&e=e1a5869b2d>

Add a preface about why this issue is so important to you personally. Tell
them now is the time. Because it is.
There are still more pro-housing bills to support.

No matter what happens with Senate Bill 50, there are still many local and
state issues that we'll continue to fight for. The next state bill priority
is Senate Bill 330, so take action now!

Timothy Gowers is leading a new collaborative research effort (polymath project) on the P vs. NP problem:
http://gowers.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/what-i-did-in-my-summer-holidays/
It's a long read, I've highlighted some important points: 
http://marker.to/wnY8PT 
(His "tiddlyspace" can be found here: http://gowers.tiddlyspace.com/#)
What's really interesting, and new in this project, is that he's making the whole process of mathematical research transparent through what he calls "proof discovery trees." It's apparent that so much more can be done if he had the websites that are especially designed for this kind of organization. 

Anyway, I'm throwing this out there in case people want ideas to work on, or know of good resources for this kind of thing.

(@Jacob: this meshes well with your IdeaOverflow idea; Gowers sets out a lot of features that would be useful from a research perspective.)

-Holden

subject: Polymath: Collaborative math research
content:
Timothy Gowers is leading a new collaborative research effort (polymath
project) on the P vs. NP problem:
http://gowers.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/what-i-did-in-my-summer-holidays/
It's a long read, I've highlighted some important points:
http://marker.to/wnY8PT  <http://marker.to/wnY8PT>
(His "tiddlyspace" can be found here: http://gowers.tiddlyspace.com/#)
What's really interesting, and new in this project, is that he's making the
whole process of mathematical research transparent through what he calls
"proof discovery trees." It's apparent that so much more can be done if he
had the websites that are especially designed for this kind of
organization.

Anyway, I'm throwing this out there in case people want ideas to work on,
or know of good resources for this kind of thing.

(@Jacob: this meshes well with your IdeaOverflow idea; Gowers sets out a
lot of features that would be useful from a research perspective.)

-Holden
html_content:
Timothy Gowers is leading a new collaborative research effort (polymath project) on the P vs. NP problem:
http://gowers.wordpress.com/2013/10/24/what-i-did-in-my-summer-holidays/
It's a long read, I've highlighted some important points: 
http://marker.to/wnY8PT 
(His "tiddlyspace" can be found here: http://gowers.tiddlyspace.com/#)
What's really interesting, and new in this project, is that he's making the whole process of mathematical research transparent through what he calls "proof discovery trees." It's apparent that so much more can be done if he had the websites that are especially designed for this kind of organization. 

Anyway, I'm throwing this out there in case people want ideas to work on, or know of good resources for this kind of thing.

(@Jacob: this meshes well with your IdeaOverflow idea; Gowers sets out a lot of features that would be useful from a research perspective.)

-Holden

subject: Opportunity to work with two of the world's best poker players
content:
Hey guys,

Two of my friends (Tom Dwan and Vivek Rajkumar) are two of the world's best
poker players and are very well connected in the casino industry. They are
working on a pretty cool idea and asked me to forward the following to
awesome people I know.

*There's a clear flaw in the taxi system model where there is no simple way
for a customer to give an opinion of their driver. Your customers are
autonomous, thinking, conscious, humans... And when possible you should try
to get a very quick snippet of their thoughts. Uber does this. Yelp does
this. In some industries it isn't worth as much.*

*At casinos I think it would be worth a significant amount. I believe it
should be fairly doable to have an RFID in every employees nametag, and an
app setup where you try to incentivize (likely by giving casino player
points) people to give their opinions on the employees they interact with.
The core idea is clearly aimed at a way smaller market than uber or yelp...
But it's also a market where you could end up with extremely accurate
ratings (which are worth more per 1opinion), and a casino employee who
messes up costs the company way more than your average bad cab driver costs
a cab company.*

Feel free to reach out to me if interested!

Best,
Prabhav Jain

html_content:
My MIT jobs list posting!

On Sep 12, 2014 2:07 PM, "Jacob Cole" <jcole@mit.edu> wrote:

My MIT Jobslist posting!

Project: index.ideajoin.jacobcole.net

"Suggestion Graph" Demo: jcr.stcatz.ox.ac.uk/ideas/; see also Graph view (refresh page once after load if necessary). Platform has 2,000+ users and caused Oxford colleges to amend constitutions to require its use.

Seeking: a very special full-time (or thesis-level) collaborator, who is ideally either a hardcore web developer or hard-core NLP/ML programmer, ideally passionate about graphs and connecting ideas/people. Ideally in Boston or Bay Area. Might anyone be able to refer anyone?

Offering: Deeply meaningful work attempting to lay the groundwork for AI's that autonomously create ideas while creating a platform to connect people and their ideas. Can pay full-time salary if necessary + founder-level equity; investment offer from billionaire Nicolas Berggruen who is in Boston next week and wants to meet up in person with potential collaborators.

Contact: Jacob Cole <jcole@mit.edu>

Hi all, I'm Jacob Cole <jcole@mit.edu>, a course 6 (Electrical Eng. and Computer Science) senior.

Right now I see the most fundamental pressing problem in the world is that human activity is scattered. 

People with synergistic ideas in research groups, big companies, and society aren't aware of each other. (Prof. Tim Berners-Lee, who's been an adviser on this project, said in 2011 "There are millions of scientists trying to cure the likes of AIDS and Alzheimer's. Maybe the cure is currently separated in different people's heads. How can we design the web so that these half-formed solutions can come together? How can we build a really creative space for scientists?") At the same time, talented people start redundant or non-meaningful startups even when there are many low-hanging and relevant ideas available. Moreover, news media has a short attention span; we hear about bombings in Syria and earthquakes in Haiti one week and something else the next, even if the problems aren't resolved. As a result, the well-being of suffering people is at the mercy of what entertains the first world.

This isn't okay.

Prof. Minsky's Society of Mind concept teaches us that a mind is a system to meditate between a collection of little agents, and that society can be thought of as a mind. This mind is currently scatterbrained.

I'm working to solve this via a project at the intersection of semantic Web, UI, and AI, creating a platform to collaboratively build graphs of ideas <index.ideajoin.jacobcole.net>, that I started nearly 2 years ago in Prof. Marvin Minsky's Society of Mind class. This summer, the project got a funding offer <funding.ideajoin.jacobcole.net> from billionaire Nicolas Berggruen, who wants to use the platform for idea management within the companies he runs. We are seeking a very special full-time collaborator on the project. Nicolas will be in Boston next week and wants to meet up in person with potential collaborators.


An introduction to the paradigm: Building the Giant Global Graph of Ideas

One tip of the iceberg of the project is an attempt to create the best-ever software for keeping and sharing lists of ideas. This software will, critically, allow users to note relationships between ideas. This is powerful; consider: right now, people who hold the pieces to each other's puzzles pass in the hallway without knowing it. One person might have a relationship between idea A and idea B in his head, another person might have relation between idea B and idea C in her head, and when they talk, they end up with a shared graph A <> B <> C . As people  all over the world have conversations and note connections, a Giant Global Graph of ideas larger than that in any individual's head, is constructed, but, until now, not captured in a central place. Prof. Tim Berners-Lee, who's been my research adviser this past year, proposes the GGG as the next evolution of the Web, and cites Facebook as one of the first major sites to capitalize on a piece of the vision.

A human-machine hybrid system to suggest related ideas:
Manually intermeshing graphs of ideas is powerful alone, but becomes even more significant when facilitated by AI. Much of my research has consisted of developing NLP/ML algorithms, with the current version based on MIT ConceptNet, a graph of >16 million commonsense concepts and the relations between them, to automatically suggest related ideas which humans can approve or reject as actually related. This is a rough analogue of Facebook's "People you may know" feature for suggesting ideas. Incidentally, this creates a new paradigm for Internet research structurally better than Google for many types of investigation <researchlists.jacobcole.net>.

My longtime friend Malcom Gilbert, who is an experienced web developer, is planning to do his AI MEng thesis with Prof. Patrick Winston, on the topic of this project. There are several professors in support of this project who have potentially be thesis advisors. If you or anyone ideal you know would like to be involved on a lower time-commitment scale, like undergraduate research, we may be able to arrange that as well.

It would be transformatively helpful to the project I'm most passionate in my life if anyone might be able to help find the right additional collaborator.

^^



--
Jacob Cole
qoɔɐɾ

Massachusetts Institute of Technology
Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
jcole@mit.edu | (858) 740-6970

subject: Re: Logarithms
content:
Nimish, this isn't a real problem. Left super scripts are a already a
widely used thing.
The plaintext notation \LaTeX uses works well enough: ^{ls}X^{rs}
Use braces where ambiguous.

The concerns thus far raised are integration implementation details.

More important is to figure out what power this new notation affords.

> be e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady
> rightward progression; in terms of character size, the expression is
> ordered 1 3 2, with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode
> this new expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes
> the ^ relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x?

html_content:
Nimish, this isn't a real problem. Left super scripts are a already a widely used thing.
The plaintext notation \LaTeX uses works well enough: ^{ls}X^{rs}
Use braces where ambiguous.

The concerns thus far raised are integration implementation details. 

More important is to figure out what power this new notation affords.



On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 4:24 PM, Nimish Pratha <nimish.pratha@gmail.com> wrote:
not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.

i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.

consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would be e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady rightward progression; in terms of character size, the expression is ordered 1 3 2, with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode this new expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes the ^ relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x? 


On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 4:14 PM, H. Lee <howonlee@stanford.edu> wrote:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetration

Best Regards,
Howon Lee


On Fri, May 9, 2014 at 4:11 PM, Rafael Cosman <rafaelc@stanford.edu> wrote:
Yo, what’s tetration?

not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.

i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual
counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions
with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.

consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would be
e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady rightward
progression; in terms of character size, the expression is ordered 1 3 2,
with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode this new
expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes the ^
relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x?

html_content:
not to be a debbie downer but there are other problems with the system.

i agree that it serves well as an immediately recognizable visual counterpart to the exponent. however, stacking logs in exponent expressions with this system becomes problematic and, personally, ugly.

consider e^(ln x). you see this all the time. under this system it would be e^(e^x) (?). herein we have two problems. one, there's no steady rightward progression; in terms of character size, the expression is ordered 1 3 2, with 1 being the largest. two, how exactly are we to encode this new expression system in plain text? the introduction of this makes the ^ relation ambiguous. is e^x e to the x, or ln x?
